prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for not keeping my husband undisturbed while he works from home.
My husband switched jobs within the past year or so and new job allows him to work from home  a few days a week.  He decided to set up his office in our bedroom.  I suggested he set up in the basement where he would be guaranteed silence and very little disruption.  He prefers to work from our bedroom because the view is better.  His job is 90% conference calls so while he is up there, I have to keep kids from disturbing him which basically means the whole top floor of our house is off limits while he is on calls.  It also means I can’t shower in my bathroom, do chores, put away laundry, or even take a nap when the baby is sleeping.  I also work from home but also take on most of the house chores and dealing with kids.  Him being up there negates my ability to take a damn shower or a poop in peace when I want to.   Since we have adequate space in the basement I told him that we would never bother him while he is down there ever but I can’t promise him silence if he stays in our bedroom. He says i am the asshole for not being quiet when he’s on calls while I think he is the asshole for not setting his office up in the dang basement. Please resolve our fight for us.  Thank you!
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's see. The user is asking if the person in the scenario is in the wrong. The situation is about a husband working from home in the bedroom, causing disruptions for the wife who also works and handles the kids and chores.

First, the husband chose to set up his office in the bedroom despite the wife suggesting the basement for fewer disturbances. The basement is quieter, but he prefers the view. His job is mostly conference calls, so he needs silence. However, the wife can't use the top floor for anything, like showering or doing chores, because the kids can't disturb him. She works from home too and manages most household tasks. She told him she can't guarantee silence if he's in the bedroom but can if he's in the basement. He thinks she's the problem for not being quiet, while she thinks he's wrong for not moving to the basement.

Hmm. The key points here are about mutual needs and compromise. Both are working from home, so they both need a space to work without interruptions. The husband's choice to stay in the bedroom despite the wife's suggestion might be causing more conflict. The wife's role includes managing the kids and chores, which are essential, and his setup is limiting her ability to do those things. 

The husband's refusal to compromise by moving to the basement might be where he's in the wrong. The wife is trying to communicate her needs, but he's not listening. The husband's job requires silence, but the wife's ability to fulfill her duties is being hindered. It seems like a balance issue. The wife isn't the one creating the disturbance; the setup is. So it's more about his choice not to compromise. Therefore, the author (the wife) isn't in the wrong. She's standing up for her needs when he's not meeting her halfway. Answer B.
